captions.text: Spider-man has some pretty sweet abilities,

but let us take a scientific look to see how well this superhero
stacks up to reality.

For spider-man to become genetically modified, the spider that
bit him would have to release a retrovirus into his body.

Retrovirus carry genetic information which
gets inserted into the DNA of cells.

The cell then reads the new DNA to create specific
functions and proteins for that cell.
But this retrovirus would have to make its way to nearly every cell

and have the ability to code for new
and different functions in each cell.

So while it is theoretically possible,
it would also be pretty "amazing".

Silk, it is actually proportionately stronger
and more flexible than steel.

Spiderwebs 1/10th the size of a piece of hair
are able to catch insects flying upwards of 15 miles an hour.

And, believe it or not, if a web were an inch thick in diameter
it could actually stop a fighter jet.

Strength, some spiders can lift up to 50 times their body weight, this muscle strength
is directly related to size.

Think about your biceps, when you work out it increases
in height and width, but not length.

In this way, the strength of an organism increases
as a square, or by 2 on the scale factor.

But as organisms get bigger, their volume increases by
height, width and length,
as a cube, or a 3 on the scale factor.

This creates a ratio of 2:3,
meaning the bigger the organism, the smaller its proportional strength.
But because Spider-man is human shaped and sized,

the retorvirus would have to encode for the creation of more
actin and myosin proteins.

These proteins effect the contraction abilities of muscles,
and in effect could make a human stronger.
Climbing walls? Not a problem for spiders,
they have tiny hairs on each leg

and these hairs have tons of even smaller
hairs with triangular ends
which interact within nanometers of the atoms on the surface.

This creates electrostatic forces, allowing them to stick with 
strength of 170 times their own weight.

Too capture this ability, Spider-man would need permanently
hairy hands and feet,
which may not overly impress his damsels in distress.
And finally, what about the Spidey Sense?

Well, spider hairs are extremely sensitive
to vibration and air pressure changes.

But this means that spider-man could
only perceive things that are near him, and not events at a distance.
Got a burning question you want answered?

Ask it in the comments, or on facebook and twitter, and subscribe for
weekly science videos.

comments.author: nicholas petros

comments.text:
+wasem gara Thank you for your detailed response. Yes, you have answered my 
question and I am thankful :D 
He never used the word "stickiness", I used the word "sickiness" as a 
substitution of saying "the strength of the spider's tiny hairs to adhere 
to the wall" as a way of shortening my sentences while still conveying my 
meaning, but I see now that that has only caused confusion lol. Thank you 
very much though :)
comments.author: blazer7811

comments.text:
+blazer7811 Well I think when he said stickiness in 1:45 he made a mistake!
spiders don't stick they use thousands of tiny hairs that makes the 
fraction between the spider leg and the surface so Great that the spider 
can carry 170x his wight.
And the answer for your question: how does he remove his legs?
the Hairs on each of the spider legs have a unique direction from the other 
legs making it "sticky" if it moves to the opposite direction of the hairs.
For example: image a spider standing on your desk and magnify his legs you 
will see that the back legs have ALL the hairs pointed to the back like 
this   \\\\\\\\\\\ and the legs get more or less "sticky" depend on the 
direction they move.
                                                   ----------> more "sticky"
                                                   <------- less "sticky"
 
Try it yourself!! get on the floor (best to be with mat on) and half close 
your fists Or make your fingers like clews, now place both hands on the mat 
and push to the back with your hands only, you will notice a great fraction 
between your fingers and the mat, now simply slide your hands Forward this 
time....... Yes your hands simply slide on the mat!!!! and this is how 
spider legs are "sticky" if he move the leg to one direction and not 
"sticky" if he move it to the other direction. 

So if the spider have EIGHT legs with each leg heirs pointing to a 
direction, If the spider push all his legs to the opposite direction he 
will simply get "sticky" and that is how they can hang upside down!

I hope I answered your question :D
comments.author: wasem gara

comments.text:
+wasem gara
Thanks for your answer but you've missed my question completely. My 
question was not "how does the spider stick to the wall?" instead my 
question is "how does the spider *remove* its self from the wall since the 
wall is so "sticky" and the spider's strength is much weaker than the 
wall's "stickiness?" 

:At :55 in the video, he says that spider's can lift up to 50x their own 
weight.
At 1:45, he says the "stickiness" to the wall can carry 170x the spider's 
weight.
170>50 therefore, in theory, the spider should not be able to remove 
himself from the wall once attached.
comments.author: blazer7811

hello!

more explaining on how do spiders do stick and move on walls search in
